entry.title: Expose all speakers upon microphone use
entry.content:
Specification title

Audio Output Devices API

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

https://github.com/w3c/mediacapture-output/pull/150/files

Explainer URL (if available)

No response

Proposal author(s)

@jan-ivar

MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaDevices/enumerateDevices

Caniuse.com URL

https://caniuse.com/?search=enumerateDevices

Bugzilla URL

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1958963

Mozillians who can provide input

@karlt, @martinthomson

WebKit standards-position

https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=284045

Other information

Safari 18.4 recently added speaker selection that aligns with Chrome behavior.

I wanted to be formal about relaxing our exposure criteria for speakers in the navigator.mediaDevices.enumerateDevices() API, to match the recent spec change in w3c/mediacapture-output#150. This is to align with other implementations for web compatibility.

The old behavior was to only expose speakers whose groupId is the same as that of any microphone, once the document is using a microphone.

The new behavior is to expose all speakers once the document is using a microphone.

The practical impact will be that websites that build in-content speaker selection UX, upon using microphone, will be able to enumerate and redirect audio output to any speakers on the user's system, not just the subset of speakers that come with a combined microphone (e.g. headsets).

We've had bug reports that our behavior is confusing, and its privacy benefit seems slight.

In-content speaker selection UX has become the norm in video conferencing.

For non-video conferencing use cases, Firefox supports speaker selection through browser UX which works without microphone .

entry.title: [WebRTC] Align browsers on RTP stats lifetimes
entry.content:
Specification title

Identifiers for WebRTC's Statistics API

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-stats/

Explainer URL (if available)

No response

Proposal author(s)

@henbos, @jan-ivar

MDN URL

No response

Caniuse.com URL

No response

Bugzilla URL

No response

Mozillians who can provide input

@jan-ivar

WebKit standards-position

WebKit/standards-positions#478

Other information

RTP stats objects, of type "outbound-rtp" or "inbound-rtp" in this case, represents a WebRTC stream. The identifier of this stream is the SSRC (a number). We should collect stats for streams that "exist", but implementations and spec has disagreed on when the stream should exist: if the SSRC information is conveyed via SDP, does the stream still exist before packets are sent or received?

Regarding outbound-rtp:

  • Chrome creates them too early (at "has-local-offer", should be at "stable")
  • Firefox creates them (according to recent spec changes) too late: not until packets are sent.

Regarding inbound-rtp:

  • Chrome creates them too early if SSRCs are conveyed in the SDP, should create them when first packet is received.
  • Firefox does it correctly and does not need to update.

WebKit/standards-positions#473

TAG review

w3ctag/design-reviews#1071

Other information

This API uses Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) to allow analysis of potentially identifiable signals while providing only a limited verdict output. For example, it empowers anti-fraud services to verify whether a user possesses an unmodified stored timestamp older than some provided timestamp without disclosing any additional user data. This approach strikes a balance between user privacy and anti-fraud capabilities by enabling websites to request a reputation signal (such as profile age) on which the user agent can enforce meaningful privacy constraints, while making the signal useful enough to remove the need for other burdensome or invasive checks, and allowing the user to clear said signal at will.

entry.title: H265 (HEVC) codec support in WebRTC
entry.content:
Specification title

WebRTC: Real-Time Communication in Browsers

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-pc/

Explainer URL (if available)

No response

Proposal author(s)

@henbos

MDN URL

No response

Caniuse.com URL

No response

Bugzilla URL

No response

Mozillians who can provide input

@jan-ivar

WebKit standards-position

N/A they have already shipped it in WebRTC according to jsfiddles

Other information

This newer codec has increased compression efficiency (higher quality per bitrate) relative to VP8/VP9/H264 and very strong hardware support going back over a decade. This translates into improved visual experience and if HW is used, increased battery life and reduced risk of performance issues. For reference, Chrome intends to only expose H265 in WebRTC if available by the user's operating system and hardware so support will always be conditional but we believe the user benefits are great and it will be better the more browsers support it (since otherwise the codec will not be chosen in the SDP negotiation, similar to what can happen with some HW specific H264 profile IDs today).

WebCodecs (Chrome M130) and MediaRecorder (I2S stage) support is available in Chrome, with WebRTC support available behind a flag. Safari already supports H265 in WebRTC according to jsfiddles. It looks like Firefox supports H265 for media playback also depending on HW sopport but the same implementation is not exposed to WebRTC yet. Would be great if it was!

Other information

The TC39 AsyncContext proposal provides a language built-in mechanism to preserve contexts across logically-connected sync/async code execution. Tracing libraries like OpenTelemetry, or application frameworks can save their contexts and fetch it at a later async continuation. The proposal is expected to be integrated with Web platform APIs, to propagate async contexts across async API boundaries, e.g. I/O, timers (elaborated in web-integration document).

Additionally, there might be concerns regarding the memory characteristic of the AsyncContext that can put on an web app. The memory-management document expands on this about how AsyncContext API is designed to be non-enumerable and how an entry can be garbage-collected.
